reviewText:
Oh Duck Dynasty, where did you go wrong?

Was it your mandatory shallow minigame-esque activities? The overly-vast wastelends of the Louisiana Bayou which you will spend hours traveling through? Was it your horrible, unresponsive controls? How about that even thinking about right clicking your mouse will minimize the game window?

No, it's not those. Even those sins could be forgiven. Where Duck Dynasty has gone wrong is in its very conception—in the idea that a game based on a reality television show centering around the manufacture of duck calls could provide any modicum of pleasure. The idea that a game in which your goal is to become less educated, less competent and less civilized such that you—a teenage boy—can fit in with a group of 40-something-year-old men. The idea that making digitzed versions of these very rednecks and voicing them with poor quality recordings, while occasionally cutting in television clips ever-so-loosely related to the plot at hand.

That's where this game went wrong. That's the concept which above any other has offended me. And that, along with everything, is why you should not play this game.

reviewText: I want to like this game, but it really needs to be fixed...  The first handful of reviews are all negative, few are helpful, and the ones which give a positive rating to the game seem like they're not real reviews, but people messing around.  Is this game secretly a joke?\nThe game suggests using a controller, so I plug in my controller.  But constantly, the instructions on screen flip back and forth, I mean rapidly, between pressing a controller button and pressing a keyboard button.  Because it keeps flipping, when I try to drive or walk, movement is staggered.  John Luke looks like he's limping.  When I first started the game and finally was able to enter the truck, all the background disappeared.\nI'll give it an A + on voices and on the backgrounds, but until the game is patched and made playable for more than 15 minutes without resetting, I can't actually say Play this game!""

reviewText:
I was disappointed that I didn't start with a beard. It must be DLC.

Who cares though? I still got to shoot ducks.

10/10

EDIT #1:

After about an hour worth of playing, this has quite possibly the best upgrade/reward system ever.

I caught 3 frogs. Got a shark face decal for my boat. I'm now the terror of the bayou. Those mallards are in for a suprise when John-Luke and his mighty shark boat come strolling through the swamp.

I don't even know what I did but I also got bull horns for the hood of a dope camouflaged F150. I'm not even a matador, but I grabbed the bull by the horns.

EDIT #2:

After playing over 15 hours, it seems to have some sort of grasp on my soul. I cannot even do the littlest of functions without drinking sweet tea, saying Hey" every time I'm asked a question
date:
and making up the best stories to make my life seem way more interesting than it actually is.

EDIT #3:

After 24 hours of playing
recommended:
I still have yet to grow a beard. I'm wondering if I have to do something more than just playing the game. I might go out and purchase some Rogaine to see if that will speed along the process. Why won't the Gods of the Dynasty of Ducks provide me with a bountiful amount of facial hair? I'm beginning to think I may be stricken with the "Yuppie".

EDIT #4

SEND HELP."

All I know is Duck Dynasty and its 11/10 quality and its prime optimization. COD? Yeah right sonny, more like huntin' ducks on lake with good ol' Si Robertson. In conclusion, if you want to pop a raging hard-on so gigantic that you could f**k the world for 72 hours, purchase this masterpiece of a game.

reviewText:
I didn't know what to expect going into this game, it turned out pretty decent in the end which is why I am recommending it.

The story mode is decent length running about 5-7 hours, in it you play as John Luke the current boss of the companies son.  From there the game is shaped as a day in the life of a Robertson as you go through your initiation into the Duck Dynasty.  The environment is open to the Robertson ranch letting you free roam and explore but mostly servers as a conduit between quests.  Quests are simple coming in four varieties all falling in line and helping to progress the story where required.

The mission types are; a Red light/Green light exercise having you sneaking around when setting up pranks, airboat races, duck hunting, and fishing.  While there are no sneak missions repeatable in the mini game series you can retry any of the other three.

The hunting experience is pretty neat, you look out from your blind for ducks to call in which requires you to press corresponding face buttons similar to rhythm games, allowing you to then pick your spot to unload as your called ducks come to settle.

Fishing was also pretty unique of a feel.  You push off dock in your little boat looking for activity around the lake (or hotspots) to set up at.  From there you continue to pursue their activity casting out your lure, waiting to react at the right timing for a bite.  Reeling it in is then a challenge of pulling back on the rod (RT) while maintaining a steady line, preventing your catch from jerking around and breaking the line (use right stick to keep reel, rod, and the sort lined up)

That's about all I can say about the game, if you're looking for an easy, laid back, hunting type game then this could be to your enjoyment.

reviewText:
I watched the first couple of series (UK TV hasn't had the pleasure of the later series yet) and thought it was nearly as hilarious as the Osbornes, (which have  a special place in my  heart  as I used to be a big Sabbath fan way back when they were big).

I purchased  the game  as I was curious to see how they would  transpose the TV reality show to PC game and was actually quite pleased with the effort.  You play as The Robertsons young John Luke on his way to becoming a man.  The game takes you thorough  various tasks such as driving an ATV, airboat racing,  duck calling, leaning how to shoot  ducks with a shotgun, to shotgun golf, fishing and frog catching,  as well as pranking  family members. I've only scratched the surface yet, but thought it was worth posting a review now.

The game is advertised as an open world game, but I found the game a little directed and linear in places. That said, I've throughly enjoyed playing the game so far and look forwards to more Roberstons fun when I next play the game.  If you've followed the Robertson family over the last six series (new 7th season starts 14th November 2014) you'll probably get a good laugh out of this game.  It won't be everyones cup of tea so I'd consder checking out the demo  of Redneck Logic  which is available HERE[www.aetv.com]. I'm  not sure whether it's actual game play as i've not checked the demo out yet.

You can see some video of game play HERE,  HERE and HERE - spoiler alert
